criterion: Provides clear and concise description of the patient's symptoms.
Does not suggest any self-diagnosis or self-treatment.
Does not provide any incorrect medical information.
Correctly highlights the importance of immediate referral to the emergency department.
Does not provide any unnecessary or redundant information.
Does not use overly technical or jargon-heavy language.
Correctly identifies the key red-flag signs that call for emergent evaluation.
Does not provide any information that may be perceived as alarmist or sensational.
Does not ignore or downplay the severity of the patient's symptoms.
Correctly emphasizes the need for urgent medical attention.
Does not provide any information that may be perceived as misleading or confusing.
Correctly suggests that the patient should seek immediate medical attention.
Does not ignore or disregard the patient's age as a relevant factor in their symptoms.
Does not provide any information that may be perceived as overly simplistic or oversimplified.
Correctly highlights the potential long-term consequences of delayed medical attention.
